item.title: If Britain Favors ‘Brexit,’ Changes Will Come Slowly
item.media:description: Those who support leaving the European Union in Clacton-on-Sea, England, during a visit by the leader of the U.K. Independence Party, Nigel Farage, on Tuesday.
item.description: For all the drama the vote would bring, change would not be instant: The separation would begin when a treaty clause with a two-year deadline is invoked.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: How Do You Stop a Future Terrorist When the Only Evidence Is a Thought?
item.media:description: French soldiers on patrol in Paris in January. For France, a nation that has one of the largest numbers of citizens fighting for the Islamic State, the caseload of potential jihadists to monitor is becoming unmanageable.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: The authorities are trying to reckon with attackers whose names had surfaced in terrorism investigations but who had crossed no legal boundary.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: News Analysis: In ‘Brexit’ Vote, David Cameron Faces Problem of His Own Making
item.description: The British leader promised an in-or-out referendum on the European Union to solve a short-term political problem. The consequences could be enormous.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: A Tour of Falluja Reveals Grim Remnants of Life Under ISIS
item.media:description: Iraqi security forces looked at literature found on top of a small cage that the Islamic State used to hold prisoners in the Nazal district of Falluja, which was liberated this month.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Iraqi forces liberating the city are finding beheaded bodies, apocalyptic streetscapes and clumps of hair from fighters who shaved to blend in with fleeing civilians.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: The Interpreter: The State Department’s Dissent Memo on Syria: An Explanation
item.media:description: President Obama at a White House briefing on Aug. 20, 2012. It was during this briefing that Mr. Obama warned of consequences if President Bashar al-Assad of Syria crossed a “red line.”
item.media:credit: Luke Sharrett for The New York Times
item.description: A memo issued last week that criticizes the Obama administration’s Syria policy is written in language that can be difficult to parse. Here’s what it means.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Boeing Takes Step Toward Deal to Sell Jetliners to Iran
item.description: The company confirmed that it had signed an agreement with Iran Air, the Iranian national airline, involving the sale of commercial aircraft.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: FARC Rebels in Colombia Reach Cease-Fire Deal With Government
item.media:description: A FARC soldier during a trek through the jungle in March.
item.media:credit: Federico Rios Escobar for The New York Times
item.description: The FARC rebels agreed to lay down their weapons in a conflict believed to have killed more than 200,000 people over half a century.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: John Ashe, Ex-Diplomat Accused in U.N. Corruption Case, Dies at 61
item.media:description: John W. Ashe, a veteran diplomat from Antigua, served as president of the United Nations General Assembly from September 2013 until the next September.
item.description: Mr. Ashe, a former president of the General Assembly, was accused in a bribery scheme that involved more than $1 million in payments from sources in China.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Amjad Sabri, Famed Sufi Singer, Is Gunned Down in Pakistan
item.description: Mr. Sabri, a prominent singer of Sufi devotional songs, had been named in a blasphemy case, and a wing of the Pakistani Taliban made an unconfirmed claim of responsibility in the killing.
item.dc:creator: ZIA ur-REHMAN and SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Lightning in India Kills More Than 70, Mostly Farmworkers
item.description: Lightning strikes that punctuated the monsoon season’s inaugural heavy rains left scores of farmers and others dead in the country’s northeast.
item.dc:creator: SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: North Korea’s Successful Missile Test Shows Program’s Progress, Analysts Say
item.media:description: Members of the Japan Self-Defense Forces set up a missile unit to be deployed in case of a North Korean rocket launch in Tokyo on Tuesday.
item.description: The Musudan ballistic missile’s launch was a success, state media said, quoting Kim Jong-un as boasting that North Korea could strike United States forces in the Pacific.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Congolese Politician, Jean-Pierre Bemba, Sentenced to 18 Years for War Crimes
item.description: Mr. Bemba, a former vice president of the Democratic Republic of Congo, led a militia that committed crimes against humanity in the Central African Republic.
item.dc:creator: MARLISE SIMONS
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Saudis Question U.N. Leader Over Report on Rights Violators
item.description: The United Nations secretary general had initially listed the Saudi-led coalition in Yemen among the armies accused of killing children in 2015, before taking it off.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Brazil Speaker Eduardo Cunha Indicted for Money Laundering and Currency Dealing
item.description: Brazil's Supreme Court on Wednesday indicted suspended speaker of the lower house Eduardo Cunha on charges of money laundering and illegal currency dealing.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Abortion Pill Orders Rise in 7 Latin American Nations on Zika Alert
item.media:description: Mifepristone, also known as RU 486, is a pill that induces an abortion. It is one the medications sold to Latin America women by Women on Web.
item.description: Orders rose from 36 to 76 percent in nations where the disease is causing babies to be born with tiny heads and damaged brains, a new study says.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. and PAM BELLUCK

item.title: Maharashtra State in India Grants Jews Minority Status
item.description: Maharashtra, which is home to an estimated 3,000 of India’s 4,500 Jews, approved the application for official recognition.
item.dc:creator: AYESHA VENKATARAMAN

item.title: Bitter ‘Brexit’ Campaign Could Turn on Record Number of Voters
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron visited a school in Bloxham, central England, on Wednesday as he campaigned for Britain to remain in the European Union.
item.description: The decision to remain in the European Union or leave the bloc will likely turn on which side can better motivate supporters to leave the home or office to vote.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE and SEWELL CHAN

item.title: ‘Brexit’ Debate Even Divides Cats (and Dogs) on Twitter
item.media:description: Where does Grumpy Cat fall in the debate over Britain leaving the European Union? The pets of Twitter are divided.
item.description: #CatsAgainstBrexit, #CatsForBrexit and other pet hashtags have started to appear as Twitter users inject some humor into the European Union debate.
item.dc:creator: ILIANA MAGRA and CHRISTOPHER MELE

item.title: Juchitán de Zaragoza Journal: Bathroom Debate Complicates Mexican Town’s Acceptance of a Third Gender
item.media:description: Ms. Mendez at home, altering a traditional Oaxacan shirt. Muxes dress as men or women, and tend to be feminine in their manners and the way they express themselves in the Zapotec language, experts say.
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.description: A push for transgender bathroom rights is unsettling the Zapotecs of southern Oaxaca, despite their long embrace of a third gender.
item.dc:creator: VICTORIA BURNETT

item.title: Refugee Who Walked Through Channel Tunnel Pleads Guilty but Is Freed
item.media:description: Abdul Rahman Haroun, a Sudanese refugee, braved speeding trains to walk 31 miles through the Channel Tunnel last summer.
item.description: Abdul Haroun, a Sudanese refugee, was sentenced to nine months in prison but was allowed to walk free because of the time he had already spent incarcerated.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Rory McIlroy Says He Won’t Attend Olympics Over Zika Concerns
item.media:description: “Even though the risk of infection from the Zika virus is considered low, it is a risk, nonetheless, and a risk I am unwilling to take,” the golfer Rory McIlroy said in a statement.
item.description: The decision makes the golfer one of the highest-profile athletes to withdraw over the health scare.
item.dc:creator: KAREN CROUSE

item.title: Jaguar Shot Dead After Olympic Torch Event in Brazil
item.description: The animal, who had apparently escaped a zoo enclosure, was shot after she moved toward a soldier, the military said.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Rescue Flight Lands at South Pole to Evacuate Sick Worker
item.media:description: The Amundsen-Scott South Pole Station in 2002. The National Science Foundation, citing medical privacy, did not disclose the identity of the sick worker at the station or that person’s condition.
item.media:credit: David McCarthy/National Science Foundation, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The plane, which used skis to land on the snow and ice, was to remain at a station for about 10 hours, the National Science Foundation said.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Victor Stanculescu, Romanian General Who Turned Against Ceausescu, Dies at 88
item.media:description: Gen. Victor Stanculescu was defense minister to the dictator Nicolae Ceausescu.
item.description: General Stanculescu helped the Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu escape after he was toppled in 1989, then engineered his trial and execution.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS

item.title: Sinosphere: Teaching Tiananmen to a New Generation
item.media:description: A student protester called on soldiers to return home as troops flooded into central Beijing on June 3, 1989, before the lethal suppression of the democracy protests around Tiananmen Square the night of June 3-4.
item.description: Rowena Xiaoqing He, who created a Harvard seminar on the 1989 Tiananmen democracy movement, discusses the challenges of the subject and the reactions from mainland Chinese students.
item.dc:creator: LUO SILING

item.title: Many Pro-Government Troops in Libya Killed in Fight With ISIS for Surt
item.description: One of the bloodiest days of fighting since forces loyal to the Tripoli-based Government of National Accord began an offensive in May to retake the city.
item.dc:creator: AGENCE-FRANCE PRESSE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: North Korea Fires 2nd Missile After Earlier Test Fails
item.media:description: The leader of North Korea, Kim Jong-un, at a parade in Pyongyang, the capital, in May.
item.description: The missile fell far short of its estimated full range, but neither the United States nor South Korea immediately dismissed the test as a failure.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sinosphere: Chinese Bank Spanks Workers, and the Internet Gives It a Flogging
item.description: The bank hired a performance coach to motivate its employees, but a video of him hitting several with a stick provoked anger instead.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: C.D.C. and States Ponder Plans to Keep Ahead of Zika
item.media:description: Part of a mosquito-fighting effort in the Virgin Islands aimed at insects carrying the Zika virus.
item.media:credit: Dennis M. Rivera Pichardo for The New York Times
item.description: The federal agency has been sketching out what it expects cities and states to need if a local case arises. That turns out to be a lot.
item.dc:creator: SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

item.title: I Sea, App That Claims It Can Find Migrants Adrift in Ocean, Is Called Misleading
item.media:description: A crowded inflatable boat with Syrian refugees drifted in the Aegean Sea between Turkey and Greece in August.
item.description: Developers say that the app is nothing but a marketing stunt because it showed users a static image of water, not real-time satellite photos of the ocean.
item.dc:creator: KATIE ROGERS
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Sweden Toughens Rules for Refugees Seeking Asylum
item.media:description: The Majid family, refugees from Syria, at their home in Backhammar, Sweden, in April. Sweden has introduced tough new restrictions on asylum seekers.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Sweden was once one of the most welcoming countries for refugees. Now its officials say they fear becoming overwhelmed.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: On the Runway: Victoria and David Beckham Declare Anti-Brexit Stance
item.media:description: David and Victoria Beckham, seen here at the 2015 British Fashion Awards, have announced their support for Britain remaining in the European Union.
item.description: Two days before the referendum, the high profile fashion couple take to social media to reveal their votes.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA FRIEDMAN

item.title: North Korean Defectors’ Detention Is Unlawful, Human Rights Lawyers Say
item.media:description: Colleagues and family members of the 12 North Korean waitresses who defected were presented to the news media in Pyongyang, North Korea, in May.
item.description: They accused the South’s spy agency of denying the 12 women access to legal services, and said that they had obtained power of attorney from the defectors’ families.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Baghdad Journal: Falluja Restaurant Is Reborn in Baghdad, Offering Nostalgia With Its Kebab
item.media:description: A waiter at Haji Hussein with a stack of kebabs wrapped in bread as the day’s iftar meal got underway. The restaurant’s kebab is legendary in Iraq, as much for its quality as for its provenance.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Long before it became a haven for jihadists, the city of Falluja was known as the home of the Haji Hussein restaurant, where locals, soldiers, tourists and businessmen all ate.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Egyptian Court Nullifies Transfer of 2 Red Sea Islands to Saudi Arabia
item.media:description: People celebrated in Cairo on Tuesday after a court overturned an agreement to give the Tiran and Sanafir islands to Saudi Arabia.
item.description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi had agreed to return Tiran and Sanafir during an April visit by the Saudi king, a move that set off protests.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF

item.title: Iranian General, Denouncing Move by Bahrain, Threatens ‘Bloody Intifada’
item.media:description: Bahraini demonstrators at a rally opposing the revocation of Ayatollah Sheikh Isa Qassim’s citizenship in Diraz, west of Manama, on Monday.
item.description: Gen. Qassem Soleimani, the high-profile leader of the elite Quds Force of the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps, deplored the “mistreatment” of a leading Shiite opposition cleric.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Chinese Court Says Environmental Agency Gave Polluter Lax Punishment
item.media:description: Chinese residents near a coal-fired power plant in Shanxi last year. Rampant environmental degradation is of great concern to ordinary people across China.
item.description: The agency was accused of not acting forcefully enough against the Qingshung Chemical Technology Company, which was found to have produced dyes without adequate safeguards.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Sinosphere: Chinese Official Whose Arrest Stirred Protests Confesses to Taking Bribes
item.media:description: Villagers in Wukan carried Chinese flags as they marched in protest on Monday after the detention of a local leader, Lin Zuluan.
item.description: His wife said she believed that the confession was forced, and it was unclear if it would have any effect in dispelling demonstrations in the fishing village of Wukan.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Palestinian, 15, Killed as Israeli Forces Sought to Halt Stone Throwing
item.description: One teenager died and four were wounded, and they appeared to be innocent bystanders who were hit while the military tried to halt Palestinians who were throwing stones and firebombs.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER and IRIT PAZNER GARSHOWITZ

item.title: Jordan Closes Border to Syrian Refugees After Suicide Car Bomb Kills 6
item.description: The kingdom, where terrorist attacks have been relatively rare, shut its last remaining entry points and declared the frontier a military zone.
item.dc:creator: RANA F. SWEIS

item.title: Stay or Go? E.U. Referendum Divides British Families
item.media:description: Leslie Driscoll, right, argued with her daughter Louise at a cafe in London. Louise is the only one in her family who wants Britain to remain in the European Union.
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times
item.description: The vote this week over Britain’s membership in the European Union has prompted deep, sometimes bitter divisions, even between mothers and children.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: What in the World: A New Verb in Mexico: Trumpear (From ‘to Punch’)
item.media:credit: Illustration by Alvaro Dominguez; photographs by MaraZe and Joseph Sohm/Shutterstock
item.description: Responding to remarks by Donald J. Trump, Mexicans are using satire, games, caricatures and other forms of ridicule to express anger and national pride.
item.dc:creator: ELI ROSENBERG

item.title: What in the World: Dog Meat and Lychees: A Pairing Meant to Make You Feel Warm Inside
item.media:credit: Illustration by Antonio de Luca; Photos by Eric Isselee and Eak Moto/shutterstock
item.description: At a festival in southern China that dog lovers condemn, the food pairing is all about energy, balance and fighting heat with heat.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: What in the World: How Many Die in a Typical Terror Attack? Fewer Than You Think
item.media:description: The sun rose behind 49 memorial crosses at a small lake near the Pulse nightclub in Orlando, Fla., last week.
item.description: Even so, what used to be symbolic acts have turned increasingly deadly, according to the Global Terrorism Database at the University of Maryland, which includes 140,000 attacks.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: R.I.P., Jo Cox. May Britain Remember Your Wisdom.
item.media:description: A wall of tributes in London on Monday for Jo Cox, a member of Britain’s Parliament who was murdered last week.
item.description: A united Europe would be a fitting legacy for a woman no longer able to influence the world in other ways.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS KRISTOF

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: For Europe, Arab Lives Matter More Than Africans’
item.description: The Continent has a two-tiered refugee policy and the results are deadly.
item.dc:creator: CHARLOTTE MCDONALD-GIBSON
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Editorial: The False Lure of Military Intervention in Syria
item.description: Calls for airstrikes against the Assad risk drawing the United States into another Middle East quagmire.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Money, Jobs and Sovereignty: Myth vs. Reality Ahead of ‘Brexit’ Vote
item.media:description: Boris Johnson, the former mayor of London, during the Brexit Battle Bus tour in York, England, in May.
item.description: As Britain prepares to vote on June 23 on European Union membership, both sides of the debate warn of dangerous outcomes. We debunk, or back up, their claims.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Q. and A.: Ramadan Is Here. What Islam’s Holiest Month Is About.
item.media:description: Muslims praying Sunday in Bali, Indonesia, on the eve of Ramadan.
item.description: A professor who specializes in Islamic studies and Middle Eastern history explains the practices and meaning of Ramadan.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
